text: He made them also to be pitied of all those that carried them captives.
text_kjv: He made them also to be pitied of all those that carried them captives.
text_niv: He caused them to be pitiedby all who held them captive.
text_esv: He caused them to be pitied by all those who held them captive.
text_nlt: He even caused their captorsto treat them with kindness.
text_msg: He poured out his mercy on themwhile their captors looked on, amazed.
text_nasb: He also made them [objects] of compassion In the presence of all their captors.
context: Psalm 106 recounts Israel's history of rebellion and God's enduring faithfulness. The psalm serves as a penitential prayer, acknowledging the nation's sins from the Exodus to the exile. Verse 46, "He made them also to be pitied of all those that carried them captives," references a specific historical context, likely the Babylonian exile, or possibly other periods of oppression experienced by the Israelites. During these times of captivity, the Israelites were subjected to harsh treatment, forced labor, and cultural assimilation. The Babylonian exile, in particular, marked a significant turning point as the Temple was destroyed, and the elite were deported to Babylon. While in exile, the Israelites maintained their religious identity, even as they faced ridicule and scorn from their captors. The surrounding pagan cultures, with their diverse pantheons and practices, viewed the Israelites' monotheistic faith as strange and perhaps even backward. The psalmist highlights a surprising turn of events, suggesting that despite their subjugation, God worked in a way that elicited pity and perhaps even respect from their oppressors. This could be interpreted as a manifestation of God's sovereign control over all nations, even those who oppose Him. The phrase "made them to be pitied" implies an active intervention of God, shifting the perception of the Israelites in the eyes of their captors. This intervention wasn't based on Israel's merit, but on God's covenant faithfulness and His desire to demonstrate His glory to the nations.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 106:46 reveals several crucial aspects of God's character and His relationship with His people. First, it demonstrates God's sovereignty even in the midst of judgment. The Israelites were suffering the consequences of their disobedience, yet God's hand was still at work, subtly influencing the hearts of their captors. This underscores that God is never absent or powerless, even when His people are experiencing the repercussions of their sin. Second, the verse highlights God's compassion and mercy. While the Israelites deserved punishment, God did not abandon them entirely. He tempered justice with mercy, prompting pity from their captors, mitigating their suffering to some degree. This reflects God's consistent pattern of showing grace to those who are undeserving. Third, it points to God's redemptive purpose. The pity shown by the captors could be seen as a precursor to eventual restoration. God's ultimate goal was not merely to punish Israel but to refine and restore them, ultimately fulfilling His covenant promises. This verse subtly hints at the possibility of reconciliation and return. Fourth, it illustrates God's ability to use even the actions of unbelievers to accomplish His purposes. The captors, likely driven by their own motives, were nevertheless instruments in God's hand, showing a measure of compassion that ultimately served God's plan. Fifth, the 'pity' wasn't necessarily altruistic benevolence. It may have been a more pragmatic assessment, perhaps seeing the futility of extreme cruelty or even recognising some value in the skills or labor of the captive Israelites. Regardless, God orchestrates even these complex motivations. Ultimately, the theological significance of this verse rests on God's unchanging character of love, mercy, and faithfulness, even amidst judgment.
application: In modern application, Psalm 106:46 offers several valuable insights for believers facing hardship or persecution. First, it reminds us that even in the midst of suffering, God is still in control. No matter how bleak the circumstances, God's sovereignty extends over every situation, including those where we feel oppressed or marginalized. We can find comfort in knowing that God is working behind the scenes, even when we cannot see it. Second, this verse encourages us to pray for those who persecute us. Just as God moved the hearts of the Israelite's captors, He can also influence the attitudes of those who oppose us. We should pray for them to have a change of heart, to see us with compassion, and to recognize the truth of the Gospel. Third, it challenges us to maintain a positive witness even in the face of adversity. Our conduct, even under duress, can impact the perceptions of those around us. By demonstrating integrity, kindness, and faith, we can create opportunities for God to soften hearts and elicit compassion. Fourth, it teaches us to trust in God's redemptive purpose. Even when we are suffering the consequences of our own mistakes or the actions of others, God can use those experiences to refine us, strengthen our faith, and ultimately bring about good. We should look for God's hand at work in our trials, trusting that He will ultimately work all things together for our good. Fifth, we should actively seek to understand and empathize with those who are different from us, even those who may be hostile. Just as the Israelites were once captives, we too can be held captive by prejudice, fear, or misunderstanding. By reaching out in love and seeking to build bridges, we can create opportunities for God to work in the hearts of others and foster reconciliation. Sixth, remember that 'pity' can translate to 'respect' when those in positions of power see the resilience and value found in those who are marginalized. Maintain excellence in all you do so that even your oppressors may see the image of God reflected in you.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your enduring faithfulness and unwavering love, even when we are undeserving. We acknowledge our shortcomings and our tendency to stray from your ways. We ask for your forgiveness and your grace to live according to your will. Lord, we lift up to you those who are suffering persecution and oppression around the world. We pray that you would soften the hearts of their oppressors and inspire compassion and mercy. Give them strength to endure their trials and to be a light in the darkness. Help us to be a voice for the voiceless and to stand in solidarity with those who are marginalized. Teach us to love our enemies and to pray for those who persecute us. May your kingdom come, and your will be done, on earth as it is in heaven. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, the verse doesn't condone captivity, but reveals God's sovereignty even in the midst of it. He uses the situation to evoke pity, not to endorse the act of oppression. God works in all circumstances to fulfill His purposes.
faqs.question: Q1: Does this verse imply God condones captivity?

faqs.answer: The extent of the 'pity' is unknown, and the verse is a theological statement more than a historical record. It suggests a degree of compassion, not necessarily a universal sentiment, orchestrated by God.
faqs.question: Q2: Was the 'pity' experienced a universal phenomenon?

faqs.answer: God's justice is seen in the Israelites' captivity, the consequence of their disobedience. His mercy is shown in prompting pity, tempering judgment and pointing towards restoration.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to God's justice?

faqs.answer: We should not expect a guaranteed outcome, but we can trust that God is working, even if it's not visible. Our focus should be on faithful witness, trusting God with the results.
faqs.question: Q4: Can we expect the same 'pity' if we face persecution today?

faqs.answer: It demonstrates that even our enemies are within God's sphere of influence, giving us hope for their potential transformation. We are called to love and pray for them.
